page.title: 06TRANSPORT
page.content: Rhewl originally meant in Welsh "Yr Hawl" = "The Right"; i.e. the right for the Drovers of 1300-1870 approx. to cross the River Clywedog at the ford on their route from Ruthin to Cerrig-Y-Drudion.A Public House bearing the name "Drover's Arms stands adjacent to the ford.Old Drover's Inns frequently have Scots Pine growing nearby, and this is no exeption, they being used as a landmark over the years. The railways arrived in 1860 with a stop at Rhewl and continuing to Rhyl which was emerging as a Holiday Resort.The line fell foul of the Beeching Axe in 1963. Road Transport is foremost today,the A 525 being a particularly busy thoroughfare,other roads being relatively quiet country lanes.
